title: 107_hr3223
content:
The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation. Additionally, it requires the Secretary to enter into a self-determination contract with the Nation upon request. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. The Jicarilla Apache Nation will plan, design, and construct water supply and wastewater systems with oversight from the Bureau of Reclamation. The Nation will assume ownership and responsibility for the system. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Act", "BIA", "Irrigation", "Reclamation", "Report", and "Reservation" related to the Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico, as defined by Public Law 106-243, includes lands held in trust by the United States for the Tribe. A Rural Water Supply Project serves various communities with clean water, and the Secretary of the Interior oversees these efforts for the Jicarilla Apache Nation. The Jicarilla Apache Reservation has a Rural Water System overseen by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation, as well as pumping and treatment facilities, distribution systems, and access roads. The Rural Water Supply Project aims to serve the Reservation's water and wastewater needs, including construction, replacement, and repair of systems. This includes buildings, access roads, property rights, and other necessary facilities like power transmission, pipelines, and pumping plants. The tribal share of the project's cost includes designing and initiating construction of the wastewater treatment plant. The Rural Water Supply Project on the Reservation includes construction of wastewater treatment plant, diversion structure replacement, raw water settling ponds, water treatment plant, storage plants, transmission pipeline, and distribution pipelines. Tribal share covers design and initial construction costs, while Federal share covers remaining project costs. Federal funding for operation and maintenance will be available as per the Indian Self-Determination Act. Upon completion of the Rural Water Supply Project, the Tribe will assume responsibility for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs in accordance with the Indian Self-Determination Act and the Operation, Maintenance, and Replacement Plan outlined in the Report. The Secretary has the authority to enter agreements and regulations to implement the Act and the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will prepare a project plan for the Rural Water Supply Project, including maps and engineering drawings. The Tribe will develop an OM&R plan for operations and maintenance. A construction manager will be selected to work with the Tribe. A memorandum of agreement will be made for the transition plan during construction. The Secretary will work with the Tribe on the planning, design, and construction of the Rural Water Supply Project. A memorandum of agreement will be established for a transition plan addressing operations and maintenance. Oversight responsibility will be with the Secretary and the Tribe, incorporating value engineering analysis. Technical assistance will be provided to the Tribe for planning, development, and construction, including operation and management training. The service area of the project will be within the Reservation boundaries, and the project will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Rural Water Supply Project on the Reservation will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Secretary will provide annual reports to Congress on the project's progress. Title to the project will be held in trust for the Tribe by the United States. Authorization of appropriations for the Rural Water Supply Project is set at $45,000,000. Funds cannot be used for construction until appraisal investigations, feasibility studies, and environmental requirements are met. Additionally, funds are prohibited from being used for irrigation purposes. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS.

The Jicarilla Apache Tribe's water rights are included in the Water Rights Settlement Act and adjudicated under New Mexico State law. These rights provide water for the municipal water system without impacting other tribal water rights or endangered species.
